metadata.case_name: Amritdhara Pharmacy v. Satya Deo Gupta

facts.text: Satya Deo Gupta, sole proprietor of Rup Bilas Company, applied on July 19, 1950 under s.14 of Trade Marks Act, 1940 for registration of 'Lakshmandhara' in Class 5 for biochemical medicinal preparation used since 1923 with annual turnover Rs.40,000/- sold throughout India and some foreign markets.

Amritdhara Pharmacy opposed registration stating 'Amritdhara' registered for their medicinal preparation introduced in 1901 (originally 'Amrit Ki Dhara' changed to 'Amritdhara' in 1903), popular with sales up to Rs.4 lakhs/year; 'Lakshmandhara' likely to deceive as similar and pass off as 'Amritdhara'.
Respondent's counter-affidavit: Names distinctly different, no pass-off possible; no objection raised since 1923; 'dhara' has no particular significance; different phial, label, packing.
Appellant filed certified copies of earlier decisions where they successfully opposed or sued for infringement against marks containing 'Amrit' or 'dhara' since 1947.

Registrar's order dated September 10, 1953: Names likely to deceive under ss.8 and 10(1); honest concurrent use since 1923 but acquiescence by appellant till Trade Mark Journal advertisement; allowed registration limited to Uttar Pradesh where sales mainly occurred.
Two appeals to Allahabad High Court under s.76: Respondent against UP limitation; appellant for total refusal.
High Court judgment March 19, 1958: No likelihood of confusion as common Hindi words with different meanings; honest concurrent user; no acquiescence; allowed all-India registration.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court on December 8, 1958.
Appellant's business started by Pandit Thakur Datta Sharma in Lahore in 1901; formed company in 1942; shifted to Dehradun post-1947 partition.
Respondent's user started small in 1923 in Uttar Pradesh, grew to Rs.43,000 turnover by 1949; advertised in common mediums from 1938.

legal_issues.text: Whether 'Lakshmandhara' so nearly resembles 'Amritdhara' as to be likely to deceive or cause confusion under ss.8 and 10(1) of Trade Marks Act, 1940.
Whether acquiescence or other special circumstances under s.10(2) permit registration despite similarity.

petitioner_arguments.text: 'Lakshmandhara' composite word used to denote same medicine as 'Amritdhara'; 'dhara' first used by appellant; likely to pass off to ultimate purchaser.
Earlier decisions show successful oppositions to marks with 'Amrit' or 'dhara'.

respondent_arguments.text: Names distinctly different, no deception possible; no objection since 1923; different packaging; 'dhara' no special significance.
Honest concurrent user since 1923 and acquiescence by appellant.

court_reasoning.text: Overall structural and phonetic similarity of 'Amritdhara' and 'Lakshmandhara' likely to deceive average purchaser of imperfect recollection buying same medicinal preparations for ailments; consider goods, customers (literate/illiterate, villagers/townsfolk), surrounding circumstances; whole word resemblance, not dissected.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unwary purchaser goes by overall similarity, not etymological meanings like 'current of nectar' vs 'current of Lakshman'.

court_reasoning.text: No monopoly claimed in common word 'dhara'; exclusive right to registered mark under s.21; earlier decisions inadmissible or irrelevant for first impression test.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Each case on own facts; tests from Pianotist, Bailey applications applied.

court_reasoning.text: Acquiescence established: Appellant aware of respondent's advertisements in common mediums from 1938, stood by as business grew from 1923 small user to Rs.43,000 turnover by 1949; honest concurrent user; limits registration to Uttar Pradesh.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Brings case within s.10(2) special circumstances.

holdings.text: 'Lakshmandhara' likely to deceive or cause confusion with 'Amritdhara' under s.10(1).
Acquiescence and honest concurrent use permit registration under s.10(2) limited to Uttar Pradesh.

precedents_cited.relevance: Tests for deceptive resemblance: judge by look/sound, goods, customers, surrounding circumstances.

precedents_cited.case_name: Corn Products Refining Co. v. Shangrila Food Products Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Approach from point of view of man of average intelligence and imperfect recollection.
Consider trade mark as whole, not dissect parts; 'Erectiks' vs 'Erector'.

statutes_cited.name: Trade Marks Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibition on deceptive marks; honest concurrent use/special circumstances for similar marks; exclusive use right.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Admissibility of prior decisions as instances of rights claimed.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment set aside; Registrar's order of September 10, 1953 restored, permitting registration of 'Lakshmandhara' limited to Uttar Pradesh.

key_quotes.text: "To such a man the overall structural and phonetic similarity of the two names Amritdhara and Lakshmandhara is likely to deceive or cause confusion."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core finding on likelihood of deception under s.10(1).

key_quotes.text: "A trade mark is likely to deceive or cause confusion by the resemblance to another already on the Register if it is likely to do so in the course of its legitimate use in a market where the two marks are assumed to be in use by traders in that market."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the opponents stood by and allowed the applicant to develop his business and... from small beginning he began to sell these medicines to the extent of about Rs. 43,000/- in 1949. In my opinion, this is acquiescence which would come under the phrase or other special circumstances in section 10(2)"
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: Registrar's finding on acquiescence upheld by Supreme Court.
